One future possible source of energy is the energy released when low-salinity waters mix with high-salinity waters, such as when rivers reach the ocean. This "gradient energy" can be harvested through a process called pressure retarded osmosis (PRO). The PRO process involves water transport from a low-salinity source through a semipermeable membrane to a high-salinity draw solution. The objective of this multidisciplinary research and education program is to develop and study advanced thin-film composite (TFC) membranes that are designed for PRO. The proposed research is transformational because it will deliver TFC PRO membranes with high water flux, low reverse salt flux, high apparent power density, and an overall structure that can withstand mechanical stresses generated during operation under high osmotic pressures. These performance and structural characteristics will be achieved by incorporating unique, previously untested nanomaterials into the membrane structure.

Studies will test the hypothesis that incorporation of specific nanomaterials directly into the thin film active layer and as a separate, ultrathin supporting layer will yield a new class of robust PRO membranes with unmatched performance characteristics. The research will provide deep understanding of how chemical functionalization of the membranes and nanomaterial additives impacts their mechanical properties and performance. Investigations will examine the roles of loading and degree of functionalization of nanomaterials on membrane compressive modulus and strength. Performance measurements will use standardized protocols and models to determine water and salt permeability coefficients, structural parameters, and apparent power densities. With this knowledge, the team will be able to design TFC PRO membranes with the desired performance.

The project will integrate education and research aimed at improving public science literacy among individuals living in Upstate South Carolina and Western North Carolina by using entertainment media education and creating social media forums that facilitate discussion of science news. Partnership with a local television program that serves over 800,000 households in the nation?s 36th largest market will ensure that on-air science demonstrations and web-based science videos reach a large and highly diverse audience. It is expected that television promotion of the demonstrations and videos to local school districts will benefit students in the viewing area by illustrating the relevance of science and supporting science learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project focused on advancing the development of pressure-retarded osmosis (PRO) membranes for harvesting clean and renewable energy from salinity gradients. PRO captures the energy released when solutions of different salt concentration are mixed by placing a semi-permeable membrane between them. The success of the PRO process to generate power depends greatly on the characteristics of the membrane that is used, with thin-film composite (TFC) membranes showing the most promise.

The initial goal of this project was to develop a new class of TFC membrane support structures using vertically-aligned, helically-coiled carbon nanotubes (HCNT). These HCNT behave like perfect springs when compressed; therefore, we hypothesized that ultrathin HCNT supports could withstand the mechanical stresses generated during PRO and increase power output. While pure HCNT supports did not fulfill this promise, using HCNTs as additives in porous nanocomposite supports was successful. The nanocomposite supports were more effective in mitigating the loss of water passage under compression, which is important for energy harvesting using PRO.

In addition to advancing PRO membrane design by improving the membrane support, we critically analyzed the role played by the backing layer on power output using commercial reverse osmosis membranes. We found that power output could be enhanced simply by replacing the backing. Ultimately, we proposed woven polyester mesh as a new, improved backing layer structure. We discovered that these new backings improved power density by up to 48% compared to commercial backings, and increased power density above the economic threshold.

After demonstrating that the power density of commercial reverse osmosis membranes could be increased to values above the threshold for economic consideration by changing the backing layer, we questioned whether further improvements could be made by post-treatments to their active layers. Our studies revealed the beneficial effect of a short-term alcohol treatment in increasing the water passage through the active layer of these membranes, without compromising salt rejection. The net effect is higher productivity and higher power output in PRO. The fundamental mechanism of this phenomenon was postulated.

Finally, we studied membrane deformation under high pressure conditions that are typical of PRO. Membrane deformation against the spacers used in a membrane model can increase salt passage and decrease power output. Deformation increases as pressure increases. Coupled with studies on membrane mechanical properties, we developed a membrane deformation model that includes membrane mechanical properties to predict the water and salt transport in PRO operations.

This project formed the basis for two PhD dissertations and one undergraduate student honors thesis. Three journal articles have been published and two others will be submitted. The published articles include three undergraduate student co-authors. One of the PhD students received the 2018-19 Graduate Research Assistant of the Year in the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at Clemson University. He was selected to participate in the Dow BEST Symposium and also completed a summer internship with Fraunhofer USA in 2019, which recognized his skills set in membrane materials selection, membrane fabrication, and performance testing.
